facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 201 of 1970 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 201 of 1970. Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment

facts.text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 3rd February, 1970 of the Delhi High Court in Crl. Mis. No. 93 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 3rd February, 1970 of the Delhi High Court in Crl. Mis. No. 93 of 1969. M. Anand, for the Appellant.

facts.text: Delhi High Court dismissed appellant's petition under s. 561-A of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is directed against an order of a learned single Judge of the Delhi High Court, dismissing appellants petition made under s. 561-A of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

facts.text: On June 15, 1969, a report was lodged in Police Station, Tilak Mark, New Delhi, by Munshi Ram.

anchor.surface_text: The material facts are these On June 15, 1969, a report was lodged in Police Station, Tilak Mark, New Delhi, by one Munshi Ram alleging that he was employed as a Driver

facts.text: Munshi Ram was employed as a Driver of bus DLP 3867 belonging to Indraj Singh and Sukh Lal of Chirag Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: by one Munshi Ram alleging that he was employed as a Driver of bus, DLP 3867, belonging to Indraj Singh and Sukh Lal of Chirag Delhi.

facts.text: On June 13, 1969 at 6 p.m., Munshi Ram stopped the bus at Mathura Road to talk to Devi Singh son of Ganesh Lal.

anchor.surface_text: On June 13, 1969 at 6 p.m., he stopped the bus at Mathura Road to talk to one Devi Singh son of Ganesh Lal.

facts.text: Devi Singh invited Munshi Ram, Mahinder Singh Conductor and Sher Singh helper to soft-drinks at a nearby shop.

anchor.surface_text: Devi Singh invited the informant and his companypanions, Mahinder Singh Conductor and Sher Singh helper, to soft-drinks at a nearby shop.

facts.text: They left the bus unattended and proceeded to the shop.

anchor.surface_text: Leaving the bus unattended, they proceeded to that shop.

facts.text: Jehan Singh appellant, Sharma, R. K. Pathak and another man of stout-build got into the bus.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, Jehan Singh appellant, Sharma, R. K. Pathak and another man of stout-build got into the vehicle.

facts.text: The stout man took the steering wheel and all four drove away in the bus despite protests of informant and companions.

anchor.surface_text: The stout man took the steering wheel, and all the four drove away in the bus despite the protests of the informant and his companypanions.

facts.text: Munshi Ram went to Chirag Delhi to inform employer Indraj Singh but found him absent.

anchor.surface_text: Munshi Ram then went to Chirag Delhi to inform his employer Indraj Singh, but found the latter absent.

facts.text: Pathak and Sharma were employed in Scindia House.

anchor.surface_text: It was also mentioned in the report that Pathak and Sharma were employed in Scindia House.

facts.text: Police started investigation and arrested Jehan Singh and R. K. Pathak.

anchor.surface_text: The police started investigation and arrested Jehan Singh appellant, and R. K. Pathak, Assistant Manager of the Industrial Credit Co. Ltd., Scindia House

facts.text: R. K. Pathak is Assistant Manager of the Industrial Credit Co. Ltd., Scindia House.

anchor.surface_text: arrested Jehan Singh appellant, and R. K. Pathak, Assistant Manager of the Industrial Credit Co. Ltd., Scindia House  hereinafter called the Company .

facts.text: Arrested persons were released on bail.

anchor.surface_text: They were later released on bail.

facts.text: Bus was seized by police from possession of the Company.

anchor.surface_text: The bus was also seized by the police from the possession of the Company.

facts.text: Pathak and appellant filed petitions under s. 561A CrPC challenging police proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: Pathak and the appellant filed two separate petitions under s. 561A, Cr. Procedure Code challenging the police proceedings in pursuance of the First Information Report

facts.text: Delhi High Court allowed Pathak's petition and quashed proceedings against him.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge by a companymon judgment allowed Pathaks petitions and quashed the proceedings against him, but dismissed the appEllants petition

facts.text: Delhi High Court dismissed appellant's petition.

anchor.surface_text: but dismissed the appEllants petition with this observation If Jehan Singh had transferred all his rights in the bus,

facts.text: At the date of filing petitions under s. 561A, no charge-sheet or complaint had been laid in court; matter still at investigation stage.

anchor.surface_text: We are told that at the date of the filing of the petitions under S. 561-A, Cr. Procedure Code, numbercharge-sheet or companyplaint had been laid in companyrt. The matter was still at the stage of investigation by the police.

facts.text: Allegations in FIR disclose offence of theft if proved.

anchor.surface_text: A plain reading of the First Information Report would show that the answer to this question must be in the negative. It is alleged therein that the bus  DLP-3867  belonged to Indraj

facts.text: Bus DLP-3867 belonged to Indraj and Sukhlal of Chirag Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: It is alleged therein that the bus  DLP-3867  belonged to Indraj and Sukhlal of Chirag Delhi and was at the material time in their possession

facts.text: Bus was in possession of owners through servants Munshi Ram, Mohinder Singh, Sher Singh.

anchor.surface_text: belonged to Indraj and Sukhlal of Chirag Delhi and was at the material time in their possession through their servants, Munshi Ram Driver, Mohinder Singh Conductor and Sher Singh Helper,

facts.text: Bus removed without consent despite opposition by four persons including Jehan Singh and R.K. Pathak.

anchor.surface_text: and that it was removed in the teeth of opposition from them, without their companysent, from their custody or possession by four persons including Jehan Singh and R. K. Pathak,

facts.text: Supreme Court holds petitions under s. 561A were premature and incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons, we would hold that the petitions under s. 561-A were liable to be dismissed as pre-mature and incompetent. On this short ground, we would dismiss this appeal.
dismissing appellants petition made under s. 561-A of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

issues.text: whether the petitions under s. 561-A to quash the proceedings which were being conducted in the course of police investigation, were incompetent

anchor.surface_text: contends that the petitions under s. 561-A to quash the proceedings which were being conducted in the course of police investigation, were incompetent. He has referred to King Emperor v. Khwaja Nazir Ahmad l  and State of West Bengal v. S. N. Basak  2 . It is maintained that in these circumstances,

issues.text: whether in the instant case, the allegations made in the First Information Report, did not, if assumed to be correct, constitute the offence of theft or its abetment against the appellant

anchor.surface_text: The question, therefore, to be considered is, whether in the instant case, the allegations made in the First Information Report, did not, if assumed to be correct, constitute the offence of theft or its abetment against the appellant. A plain reading of the First Information Report would show that the answer to this question must be in the negative.

issues.text: whether the proceedings sought to be quashed were pending in any court or before the police

anchor.surface_text: At the outset, we inquired from Shri Anand, learned Counsel for the appellant, whether the proceedings sought to be quashed were pending in any court or before the police. We are told that at the date of the filing of the petitions under S. 561-A, Cr. Procedure Code,

arguments.claim: Petitions under s. 561-A to quash proceedings conducted in the course of police investigation were incompetent

anchor.surface_text: Shri Prasad, learned Counsel for the State contends that the petitions under s. 561-A to quash the proceedings which were being conducted in the course of police investigation, were incompetent. He has referred to King Emperor v. Khwaja Nazir Ahmad l  and State of West Bengal v. S. N. Basak  2 . It is maintained that in these circumstances,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: r v. Khwaja Nazir Ahmad l  and State of West Benga

arguments.court_reasoning: Preliminary objection must prevail; applied principles from cited precedents

arguments.claim: Petitions of both Pathak and Jehan Singh ought to have been dismissed as premature

anchor.surface_text: It is maintained that in these circumstances, the petitions of both Pathak and the appellant Jehan Singh ought to have been dismissed as premature.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the companyrse of investigation including the hire-purchase agreement, partnership deed and the receipt etc. would companyfirm or falsify the allegat

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed petitions premature but noted High Court already quashed Pathak's

arguments.claim: Case falls within exception to general rule against interference; reliance on R.P. Kapur v. State of Punjab

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand Shri Anand maintains that his case falls within one of the exceptions to the general rule enunciated in the cases cited  1  71 I.A. 203 at 213.  2  1963 2 S.C.R. 54. by Shri Prasad. Reliance has been placed on R. P. Kapur v. State of Punjab 1 .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: cise of its juris- diction under S. 561-A, the High Court cannot embark upon an enquiry as to whether the evidence in the case is reliable or number.

arguments.court_reasoning: Allegations in FIR do constitute offence of theft; Kapur exception not attracted

arguments.claim: Functions of judiciary and police are complementary not overlapping; courts' functions begin when charge preferred; s. 561-A preserves inherent powers but gives no new powers

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that the preliminary objection raised by Shri Prasad ,must prevail. In King Emperor v. Khwaja Nazir Ahmad  supra , their Lordship ,of the Privy Council pointed out that the functions of the judiciary and the police are complementary, not overlapping and that the courts. functions begin when a charge is preferred before it, and not until then.

arguments.claim: Police has statutory right to investigate cognizable offences under Chapter XIV CrPC (ss.154,156) without Magistrate's authority; cannot be interfered by s.439 or s.561A

anchor.surface_text: It was added that it has sometimes been thought that s. 561-A has given increased powers to the Court which it did not possess before that section was enacted. But this is not so, the section gives no new powers, it only provides that those which the court- already inherently possesses shall be preserved. The principle enunciated in Khwaja Nazir Ahmeds case  supra  was applied by this Court in S. N. Basaks case  supra .

arguments.claim: Allegations in FIR, even taken at face value, constitute offence of theft or abetment; Kapur exception not applicable

anchor.surface_text: Cases may also arise where the allegations in the First Information Report or the complaint, even if they are taken at their face value and accepted in their entirety, do not constitute the offence alleged... it would be legitimate for the High Court to hold that it would be manifestly unjust to allow the process of the criminal court to be issued against the accused person.

arguments.claim: If Jehan Singh transferred all rights in bus against hire-purchase agreement, trial court to decide if guilty of theft based on FIR version

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge by a common judgment allowed Pathaks petitions and quashed the proceedings against him, but dismissed the appellants petition with this observation If Jehan Singh had transferred all his rights in the bus, though against the stipulations in the hire-purchase agreement, it would be a matter for consideration of the trial court whether he could be regarded guilty of the offence of theft

arguments.claim: Petitions under s.561A premature and incompetent as no charge-sheet filed, matter at police investigation stage

anchor.surface_text: At the outset, we inquired from Shri Anand, learned Counsel for the appellant, whether the proceedings sought to be quashed were pending in any court or before the police. We are told that at the date of the filing of the petitions under S. 561-A, Cr. Procedure Code, no charge-sheet or complaint had been laid in court. The matter was still at the stage of investigation by the police.

arguments.claim: High Court cannot appraise evidence reliability or interfere before charge-sheet under s.173

anchor.surface_text: But, the High Court, at this stage, as was pointed out by this Court in R. P. Kapurs case  supra , could not, in the exercise of its inherent jurisdiction, appraise that evidence or enquire as to whether it was reliable or not. Might be, after collecting all the evidence, the police would itself submit a cancellation report. If, however, a charge-sheet is laid before the Magistrate under s. 173, Criminal Procedure Code,

holdings.text: the petitions under s. 561-A were liable to be dismissed as pre-mature and incompetent

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons, we would hold that the petitions under s. 561-A were liable to be dismissed as pre-mature and incompetent. On this short ground, we would dismiss this appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proceedings at police investigation stage with no charge-sheet filed; courts cannot interfere per Khwaja Nazir Ahmad and S.N. Basak; preliminary objection prevails

holdings.text: allegations made in the First Information Report, if assumed to be correct, did constitute the offence of theft or its abetment against the appellant

anchor.surface_text: The question, therefore, to be considered is, whether in the instant case, the allegations made in the First Information Report, did not, if assumed to be correct, constitute the offence of theft or its abetment against the appellant. A plain reading of the First Information Report would show that the answer to this question must be in the negative. It is alleged therein that the bus  DLP-3867  belonged to Indraj

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain reading of FIR shows bus taken without consent from possession of owners; discloses cognizable offence; R.P. Kapur exception not attracted

holdings.text: statutory power of the police to investigate cannot be interfered with by the exercise of power under s. 439 or under the inherent power of the court under s. 561-A

anchor.surface_text: and under these sections the police has the statutory right to investigate into the circumstances of any alleged cognizable offence without authority from a Magistrate and this statutory power of the police to investigate cannot be interfered with by the exercise of power under s. 439 or under the inherent power of the court under s. 561-A of Criminal Procedure Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Chapter XIV CrPC grants police independent investigation powers for cognizable offences; inherent powers complementary, not overlapping; following S.N. Basak

holdings.text: s. 561-A gives no new powers, it only provides that those which the court already inherently possesses shall be preserved

anchor.surface_text: But this is not so, the section gives no new powers, it only provides that those which the court- already inherently possesses shall be preserved. The principle enunciated in Khwaja Nazir Ahmeds case  supra  was applied by this Court in S. N. Basaks case  supra .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section codifies pre-existing inherent powers; no expansion; per Khwaja Nazir Ahmad

holdings.text: High Court cannot, in exercise of inherent jurisdiction under s. 561-A, appraise evidence or enquire as to whether it was reliable at pre-charge-sheet stage

anchor.surface_text: But, the High Court, at this stage, as was pointed out by this Court in R. P. Kapurs case  supra , could not, in the exercise of its inherent jurisdiction, appraise that evidence or enquire as to whether it was reliable or not.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pre-trial stage inappropriate for evidence appraisal; per R.P. Kapur; Magistrate decides post s.173 charge-sheet

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons, we would hold that the petitions under s. 561-A were liable to be dismissed as pre-mature and incompetent. On this short ground, we would dismiss this appeal.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed on the short ground that the petitions under s. 561-A CrPC were premature and incompetent as the matter was at the stage of police investigation.
